tissue.label: root
description: A plant axis (PO:0025004) that lacks shoot axis nodes (PO:0005004) and usually grows indeterminately.

Roots function in the absorption of water and inorganic nutrients, anchoring the plant body to the substrate and supporting it, storage of food and nutrients, and vegetative reproduction. The roots of most vascular plant species enter into symbiosis with soil-borne microorganisms. Roots are usually positively geotropic and found underground, although there are many exceptions such as the aerial roots of orchids. Roots often form secondary thickening from the root lateral meristem (PO:0006308). Commonly thought of as one of the three basic parts of the plant body, along with the shoot axis (PO:0025029) and leaves (PO:0025034).

treatment.label: drought environment
description: an environment in plant experiments to understand how plants respond to episodic drought and watering pulse by depriving the plants of water supply

シュート由来苗条系 (Japanese, exact)

treatment.label: warm/hot temperature regimen
description: The treatment involving an exposure to above optimal temperature, which may depend on the study type or the regional environment.

tissue.label: shoot-borne shoot system
description: A shoot system that is initiated from a shoot.
synonyms: sistema de epiblasto (epiblastema) que nace en el epiblasto (epiblastema) (Spanish, exact)

treatment.label: plant experimental condition
description: A plant exposure (PECO:0001001) and/or study type (PECO:0007231) applied to a whole plant (PO:0000003), a plant structure (PO:00090119), and/or a plant population as part of an experiment to evaluate the plant response.

The Plant Experimental Condition Ontology describes the treatments, growing conditions, and/or study types used in various types of plant biology experiments. The subjects of the studies may also include in vitro plant structures (PO:0000004). The broadest classes are the plant study types (PECO:0007231), where the terms describe the type of growth facility used in an experiment.  Each study type such as field study (PECO:0007256), growth chamber study (PECO:0007269), greenhouse study (PECO:0007248), or laboratory study (PECO:0007255) will also involve different growing conditions, and may also include specific biotic (PECO:0007357) and/or abiotic (PECO:0007191) plant treatments.  A plant treatment (PECO:0001001) may be a component of a plant experimental condition (PECO:0007359), and the plant study type (PECO:0007231).

tissue.label: rosette leaf
description: A vascular leaf (PO:0009025) born in a circular pattern around a stem (PO:0009047) with compressed stem internodes (PO:0020142).
Arabidopsis, vegetative development is characterized by the production of the rosette leaves.

treatment.label: age-related macular degeneration
description: Age-related loss of vision in the central portion of the retina (macula), secondary to retinal degeneration.

Degenerative changes in the RETINA usually of older adults which results in a loss of vision in the center of the visual field (the MACULA LUTEA) because of damage to the retina. It occurs in dry and wet forms.
Degenerative changes in the macula lutea of the retina.

treatment.label: age-related macular degeneration
description: Age-related loss of vision in the central portion of the retina (macula), secondary to retinal degeneration.

Degenerative changes in the RETINA usually of older adults which results in a loss of vision in the center of the visual field (the MACULA LUTEA) because of damage to the retina. It occurs in dry and wet forms.
Degenerative changes in the macula lutea of the retina.

tissue.label: seedling development stage
description: A sporophyte vegetative stage (PO:0007134) that succeeds the seed germination stage (PO:0007057) and terminates with the development of the first adult vascular leaf (PO:0006340).
This terms is used only for seed plants, although non-seed plants may have a comparable phase during which they produce juvenile or transition leaves.

treatment.label: drought environment
description: an environment in plant experiments to understand how plants respond to episodic drought and watering pulse by depriving the plants of water supply

description: A phyllome (PO:0006001) that is not associated with a reproductive structure.

description: A biological process of some plant (PO whole plant, or NCBI viridiplantae) caused by exposure to an environment containing some stressor agent.

treatment.label: warm/hot temperature regimen
description: The treatment involving an exposure to above optimal temperature, which may depend on the study type or the regional environment.

tissue.label: leaf
description: A phyllome (PO:0006001) that is not associated with a reproductive structure.

treatment.label: plant experimental condition
description: A plant exposure (PECO:0001001) and/or study type (PECO:0007231) applied to a whole plant (PO:0000003), a plant structure (PO:00090119), and/or a plant population as part of an experiment to evaluate the plant response.

The Plant Experimental Condition Ontology describes the treatments, growing conditions, and/or study types used in various types of plant biology experiments. The subjects of the studies may also include in vitro plant structures (PO:0000004). The broadest classes are the plant study types (PECO:0007231), where the terms describe the type of growth facility used in an experiment.  Each study type such as field study (PECO:0007256), growth chamber study (PECO:0007269), greenhouse study (PECO:0007248), or laboratory study (PECO:0007255) will also involve different growing conditions, and may also include specific biotic (PECO:0007357) and/or abiotic (PECO:0007191) plant treatments.  A plant treatment (PECO:0001001) may be a component of a plant experimental condition (PECO:0007359), and the plant study type (PECO:0007231).

tissue.label: root
description: A plant axis (PO:0025004) that lacks shoot axis nodes (PO:0005004) and usually grows indeterminately.

Roots function in the absorption of water and inorganic nutrients, anchoring the plant body to the substrate and supporting it, storage of food and nutrients, and vegetative reproduction. The roots of most vascular plant species enter into symbiosis with soil-borne microorganisms. Roots are usually positively geotropic and found underground, although there are many exceptions such as the aerial roots of orchids. Roots often form secondary thickening from the root lateral meristem (PO:0006308). Commonly thought of as one of the three basic parts of the plant body, along with the shoot axis (PO:0025029) and leaves (PO:0025034).

tissue.label: L mature pollen stage
description: Stage of microgametophyte development during which the pollen reaches mature stage and desiccates.
Mature pollen stages is reached at three-celled pollen in some angiosperms (maize, rice and Arabidopsis), while in others, the maturepollen has two haploid cells (tobacco, snapdragon).

treatment.label: tunicamycin
description: A mixture of antiviral nucleoside antibiotics produced by Streptomyces lysosuperificus. It contains at least 10 homologues comprising uracil, N-acetylglucosamine, an 11-carbon aminodialdose called tunicamine, and a fatty acid linked to the amino group of the tunicamine.  The homologues vary in the composition of the fatty acid moiety.

treatment.label: L-proline
description: Pyrrolidine in which the pro-S hydrogen at position 2 is substituted by a carboxylic acid group. L-Proline is the only one of the twenty DNA-encoded amino acids which has a secondary amino group alpha to the carboxyl group. It is an essential component of collagen and is important for proper functioning of joints and tendons. It also helps maintain and strengthen heart muscles.

tissue.label: seedling development stage
description: A sporophyte vegetative stage (PO:0007134) that succeeds the seed germination stage (PO:0007057) and terminates with the development of the first adult vascular leaf (PO:0006340).
This terms is used only for seed plants, although non-seed plants may have a comparable phase during which they produce juvenile or transition leaves.

tissue.label: seedling development stage
description: A sporophyte vegetative stage (PO:0007134) that succeeds the seed germination stage (PO:0007057) and terminates with the development of the first adult vascular leaf (PO:0006340).
This terms is used only for seed plants, although non-seed plants may have a comparable phase during which they produce juvenile or transition leaves.

treatment.label: warm/hot temperature regimen
description: The treatment involving an exposure to above optimal temperature, which may depend on the study type or the regional environment.

treatment.label: control
description: A control role is borne by a material in a process in which results obtained from an experimental sample and a control sample are compared.

tissue.label: root
description: A plant axis (PO:0025004) that lacks shoot axis nodes (PO:0005004) and usually grows indeterminately.

Roots function in the absorption of water and inorganic nutrients, anchoring the plant body to the substrate and supporting it, storage of food and nutrients, and vegetative reproduction. The roots of most vascular plant species enter into symbiosis with soil-borne microorganisms. Roots are usually positively geotropic and found underground, although there are many exceptions such as the aerial roots of orchids. Roots often form secondary thickening from the root lateral meristem (PO:0006308). Commonly thought of as one of the three basic parts of the plant body, along with the shoot axis (PO:0025029) and leaves (PO:0025034).

Roots are usually positively geotropic and found underground, although there are many exceptions such as the aerial roots of orchids. Roots often form secondary thickening from the root lateral meristem (PO:0006308). Commonly thought of as one of the three basic parts of the plant body, along with the shoot axis (PO:0025029) and leaves (PO:0025034).

description: The usually underground part of a seed plant body that originates usually from the hypocotyl, functions as an organ of absorption, aeration, and food storage or as a means of anchorage and support, and differs from a stem especially in lacking nodes, buds, and leaves.

tissue.label: shoot system
description: A collective plant organ structure (PO:0025007) that produces shoot-borne portions of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) and the plant structures (PO:0009011) that arise from them.

The shoot system is generally used to refer to the above-ground plant parts, although some plants have parts of their shoot system underground. For example, a rhizome (PO:0004542), bulb (PO:0025356), a corm (PO:0025355) or a subterranean tuber (PO:0004547), as in Solanum tuberosum (potato) or yam, are all part of the shoot system.
synonyms: シュート系、苗条系 (Japanese, exact)

tissue.label: seedling development stage
description: A sporophyte vegetative stage (PO:0007134) that succeeds the seed germination stage (PO:0007057) and terminates with the development of the first adult vascular leaf (PO:0006340).
This terms is used only for seed plants, although non-seed plants may have a comparable phase during which they produce juvenile or transition leaves.

treatment.label: warm/hot temperature regimen
description: The treatment involving an exposure to above optimal temperature, which may depend on the study type or the regional environment.

treatment.label: plant experimental condition
description: A plant exposure (PECO:0001001) and/or study type (PECO:0007231) applied to a whole plant (PO:0000003), a plant structure (PO:00090119), and/or a plant population as part of an experiment to evaluate the plant response.

The Plant Experimental Condition Ontology describes the treatments, growing conditions, and/or study types used in various types of plant biology experiments. The subjects of the studies may also include in vitro plant structures (PO:0000004). The broadest classes are the plant study types (PECO:0007231), where the terms describe the type of growth facility used in an experiment.  Each study type such as field study (PECO:0007256), growth chamber study (PECO:0007269), greenhouse study (PECO:0007248), or laboratory study (PECO:0007255) will also involve different growing conditions, and may also include specific biotic (PECO:0007357) and/or abiotic (PECO:0007191) plant treatments.  A plant treatment (PECO:0001001) may be a component of a plant experimental condition (PECO:0007359), and the plant study type (PECO:0007231).

tissue.label: shoot system
description: A collective plant organ structure (PO:0025007) that produces shoot-borne portions of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) and the plant structures (PO:0009011) that arise from them.

The shoot system is generally used to refer to the above-ground plant parts, although some plants have parts of their shoot system underground. For example, a rhizome (PO:0004542), bulb (PO:0025356), a corm (PO:0025355) or a subterranean tuber (PO:0004547), as in Solanum tuberosum (potato) or yam, are all part of the shoot system.
synonyms: シュート系、苗条系 (Japanese, exact)

tissue.label: shoot system
description: A collective plant organ structure (PO:0025007) that produces shoot-borne portions of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) and the plant structures (PO:0009011) that arise from them.

The shoot system is generally used to refer to the above-ground plant parts, although some plants have parts of their shoot system underground. For example, a rhizome (PO:0004542), bulb (PO:0025356), a corm (PO:0025355) or a subterranean tuber (PO:0004547), as in Solanum tuberosum (potato) or yam, are all part of the shoot system.
synonyms: シュート系、苗条系 (Japanese, exact)

treatment.label: drought environment
description: an environment in plant experiments to understand how plants respond to episodic drought and watering pulse by depriving the plants of water supply

tissue.label: seedling development stage
description: A sporophyte vegetative stage (PO:0007134) that succeeds the seed germination stage (PO:0007057) and terminates with the development of the first adult vascular leaf (PO:0006340).
This terms is used only for seed plants, although non-seed plants may have a comparable phase during which they produce juvenile or transition leaves.

treatment.label: control
description: A control role is borne by a material in a process in which results obtained from an experimental sample and a control sample are compared.

treatment.label: experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis
description: An autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system that is produced experimentally in animals by the injection of homogenized brain or spinal cord in Freund's adjuvant. Myelin basic protein appears to be the antigen that elicits the hypersensitivity immune response which is characterized by focal areas of lymphocyte and macrophage infiltration into the brain, associated with demyelination and destruction of the blood-brain barrier. Experimental allergic encephalomyelitis (EAE) is used as an animal model for demyelinating diseases of the human central nervous system such as multiple sclerosis.

An experimental animal model for central nervous system demyelinating disease. Inoculation with a white matter emulsion combined with FREUND'S ADJUVANT, myelin basic protein, or purified central myelin triggers a T cell-mediated immune response directed towards central myelin. The pathologic features are similar to MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS, including perivascular and periventricular foci of inflammation and demyelination. Subpial demyelination underlying meningeal infiltrations also occurs, which is also a feature of ENCEPHALOMYELITIS, ACUTE DISSEMINATED. Passive immunization with T-cells from an afflicted animal to a normal animal also induces this condition. (From Immunol Res 1998;17(1-2):217-27; Raine CS, Textbook of Neuropathology, 2nd ed, p604-5)

tissue.label: skin epidermis
description: The outer epithelial layer of the skin that is superficial to the dermis.

tissue.label: cerebral cortex
description: The thin layer of gray matter on the surface of the cerebral hemisphere that develops from the telencephalon. It consists of the neocortex (6 layered cortex or isocortex), the hippocampal formation and the olfactory cortex.

tissue.label: skin epidermis
description: The outer epithelial layer of the skin that is superficial to the dermis.

tissue.label: skin epidermis
description: The outer epithelial layer of the skin that is superficial to the dermis.

tissue.label: endodermis
description: A portion of ground tissue (PO:0025059) that is the inner most layer of a cortex (PO:0005708) and has a casparian strip in its anticlinal cell walls.
Forms a sheath around the vascular system. It may have secondary walls later, part_of cortex.

tissue.label: skin epidermis
description: The outer epithelial layer of the skin that is superficial to the dermis.

tissue.label: stele
description: A cardinal organ part (PO:0025001) that is the central column of a plant axis that consists of the primary vascular tissue and associated ground tissue.
If a pith is present, it is part of the stele, otherwise the stele only includes the primary vascular tissue and the ground tissue that surrounds it.

description: A portion of ground tissue (PO:0025059) that is the inner most layer of a cortex (PO:0005708) and has a casparian strip in its anticlinal cell walls.

tissue.label: seedling development stage
description: A sporophyte vegetative stage (PO:0007134) that succeeds the seed germination stage (PO:0007057) and terminates with the development of the first adult vascular leaf (PO:0006340).
This terms is used only for seed plants, although non-seed plants may have a comparable phase during which they produce juvenile or transition leaves.

tissue.label: plant embryo true leaf formation stage
description: A plant embryo development stage (PO:0007631) that occurs during the interval between the beginning of the formation of the first vascular leaf primordium (PO:0000017) in the plant embryo proper (PO:0000001), and the onset of a mature plant embryo stage (PO:0001081).

A true leaf is vascular leaf (PO:0009025) that forms after the formation of the cotyledons (PO:0020030) or a coleoptile (PO:0020033). Not all species form true leaves in the plant embryo development stage (PO:0007631). If it occurs, a plant embryo true leaf formation stage is preceded by either a plant embryo cotyledonary stage (PO:0001078) or a plant embryo coleoptilar stage (PO:0001094), depending upon the species.

description: A plant embryo development stage (PO:0007631) that occurs during the interval between the beginning of the formation of the first vascular leaf primordium (PO:0000017) in the plant embryo proper (PO:0000001), and the onset of a mature plant embryo stage (PO:0001081).

A true leaf is vascular leaf (PO:0009025) that forms after the formation of the cotyledons (PO:0020030) or a coleoptile (PO:0020033). Not all species form true leaves in the plant embryo development stage (PO:0007631). If it occurs, a plant embryo true leaf formation stage is preceded by either a plant embryo cotyledonary stage (PO:0001078) or a plant embryo coleoptilar stage (PO:0001094), depending upon the species.

tissue.label: seedling development stage
description: A sporophyte vegetative stage (PO:0007134) that succeeds the seed germination stage (PO:0007057) and terminates with the development of the first adult vascular leaf (PO:0006340).
This terms is used only for seed plants, although non-seed plants may have a comparable phase during which they produce juvenile or transition leaves.

tissue.label: shoot system
description: A collective plant organ structure (PO:0025007) that produces shoot-borne portions of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) and the plant structures (PO:0009011) that arise from them.

The shoot system is generally used to refer to the above-ground plant parts, although some plants have parts of their shoot system underground. For example, a rhizome (PO:0004542), bulb (PO:0025356), a corm (PO:0025355) or a subterranean tuber (PO:0004547), as in Solanum tuberosum (potato) or yam, are all part of the shoot system.
synonyms: シュート系、苗条系 (Japanese, exact)

treatment.label: control
description: A control role is borne by a material in a process in which results obtained from an experimental sample and a control sample are compared.

tissue.label: root structure
description: The usually underground part of a seed plant body that originates usually from the hypocotyl, functions as an organ of absorption, aeration, and food storage or as a means of anchorage and support, and differs from a stem especially in lacking nodes, buds, and leaves.

description: A control role is borne by a material in a process in which results obtained from an experimental sample and a control sample are compared.

tissue.label: root structure
description: The usually underground part of a seed plant body that originates usually from the hypocotyl, functions as an organ of absorption, aeration, and food storage or as a means of anchorage and support, and differs from a stem especially in lacking nodes, buds, and leaves.

treatment.label: control
description: A control role is borne by a material in a process in which results obtained from an experimental sample and a control sample are compared.

tissue.label: shoot system
description: A collective plant organ structure (PO:0025007) that produces shoot-borne portions of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) and the plant structures (PO:0009011) that arise from them.

The shoot system is generally used to refer to the above-ground plant parts, although some plants have parts of their shoot system underground. For example, a rhizome (PO:0004542), bulb (PO:0025356), a corm (PO:0025355) or a subterranean tuber (PO:0004547), as in Solanum tuberosum (potato) or yam, are all part of the shoot system.
synonyms: シュート系、苗条系 (Japanese, exact)

treatment.label: age-related macular degeneration
description: Age-related loss of vision in the central portion of the retina (macula), secondary to retinal degeneration.

Degenerative changes in the RETINA usually of older adults which results in a loss of vision in the center of the visual field (the MACULA LUTEA) because of damage to the retina. It occurs in dry and wet forms.
Degenerative changes in the macula lutea of the retina.

description: A portion of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) that gives rise to a portion of ground tissue (PO:0025059).

treatment.label: control
description: A control role is borne by a material in a process in which results obtained from an experimental sample and a control sample are compared.

tissue.label: root
description: A plant axis (PO:0025004) that lacks shoot axis nodes (PO:0005004) and usually grows indeterminately.

Roots function in the absorption of water and inorganic nutrients, anchoring the plant body to the substrate and supporting it, storage of food and nutrients, and vegetative reproduction. The roots of most vascular plant species enter into symbiosis with soil-borne microorganisms. Roots are usually positively geotropic and found underground, although there are many exceptions such as the aerial roots of orchids. Roots often form secondary thickening from the root lateral meristem (PO:0006308). Commonly thought of as one of the three basic parts of the plant body, along with the shoot axis (PO:0025029) and leaves (PO:0025034).

tissue.label: shoot system
description: A collective plant organ structure (PO:0025007) that produces shoot-borne portions of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) and the plant structures (PO:0009011) that arise from them.

The shoot system is generally used to refer to the above-ground plant parts, although some plants have parts of their shoot system underground. For example, a rhizome (PO:0004542), bulb (PO:0025356), a corm (PO:0025355) or a subterranean tuber (PO:0004547), as in Solanum tuberosum (potato) or yam, are all part of the shoot system.
synonyms: シュート系、苗条系 (Japanese, exact)

tissue.label: seedling development stage
description: A sporophyte vegetative stage (PO:0007134) that succeeds the seed germination stage (PO:0007057) and terminates with the development of the first adult vascular leaf (PO:0006340).
This terms is used only for seed plants, although non-seed plants may have a comparable phase during which they produce juvenile or transition leaves.

treatment.label: light
description: The photoperiod and type (e.g., natural, restricted wavelength) of light exposure.

tissue.label: seedling development stage
description: A sporophyte vegetative stage (PO:0007134) that succeeds the seed germination stage (PO:0007057) and terminates with the development of the first adult vascular leaf (PO:0006340).
This terms is used only for seed plants, although non-seed plants may have a comparable phase during which they produce juvenile or transition leaves.

description: The treatment involving an exposure to above optimal temperature, which may depend on the study type or the regional environment.

tissue.label: root structure
description: The usually underground part of a seed plant body that originates usually from the hypocotyl, functions as an organ of absorption, aeration, and food storage or as a means of anchorage and support, and differs from a stem especially in lacking nodes, buds, and leaves.

treatment.label: salt treatment
description: A chemical treatment (EO:0007189) involving use of salts as supplement to liquid and soil growth media to study various types of responses on their application.
This treatment may be used to simulate the growth conditions of sea coast regions and saline/sodic soils.

This treatment may be used to simulate the growth conditions of sea coast regions and saline/sodic soils.

tissue.label: shoot system
description: A collective plant organ structure (PO:0025007) that produces shoot-borne portions of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) and the plant structures (PO:0009011) that arise from them.

The shoot system is generally used to refer to the above-ground plant parts, although some plants have parts of their shoot system underground. For example, a rhizome (PO:0004542), bulb (PO:0025356), a corm (PO:0025355) or a subterranean tuber (PO:0004547), as in Solanum tuberosum (potato) or yam, are all part of the shoot system.
synonyms: シュート系、苗条系 (Japanese, exact)

treatment.label: salt treatment
description: A chemical treatment (EO:0007189) involving use of salts as supplement to liquid and soil growth media to study various types of responses on their application.
This treatment may be used to simulate the growth conditions of sea coast regions and saline/sodic soils.

tissue.label: root structure
description: The usually underground part of a seed plant body that originates usually from the hypocotyl, functions as an organ of absorption, aeration, and food storage or as a means of anchorage and support, and differs from a stem especially in lacking nodes, buds, and leaves.

tissue.label: rosette leaf
description: A vascular leaf (PO:0009025) born in a circular pattern around a stem (PO:0009047) with compressed stem internodes (PO:0020142).
Arabidopsis, vegetative development is characterized by the production of the rosette leaves.

description: The D-enantiomer of mannitol.

tissue.label: plant embryo true leaf formation stage
description: A plant embryo development stage (PO:0007631) that occurs during the interval between the beginning of the formation of the first vascular leaf primordium (PO:0000017) in the plant embryo proper (PO:0000001), and the onset of a mature plant embryo stage (PO:0001081).

A true leaf is vascular leaf (PO:0009025) that forms after the formation of the cotyledons (PO:0020030) or a coleoptile (PO:0020033). Not all species form true leaves in the plant embryo development stage (PO:0007631). If it occurs, a plant embryo true leaf formation stage is preceded by either a plant embryo cotyledonary stage (PO:0001078) or a plant embryo coleoptilar stage (PO:0001094), depending upon the species.

description: A plant embryo development stage (PO:0007631) that occurs during the interval between the beginning of the formation of the first vascular leaf primordium (PO:0000017) in the plant embryo proper (PO:0000001), and the onset of a mature plant embryo stage (PO:0001081).

A true leaf is vascular leaf (PO:0009025) that forms after the formation of the cotyledons (PO:0020030) or a coleoptile (PO:0020033). Not all species form true leaves in the plant embryo development stage (PO:0007631). If it occurs, a plant embryo true leaf formation stage is preceded by either a plant embryo cotyledonary stage (PO:0001078) or a plant embryo coleoptilar stage (PO:0001094), depending upon the species.

tissue.label: seedling development stage
description: A sporophyte vegetative stage (PO:0007134) that succeeds the seed germination stage (PO:0007057) and terminates with the development of the first adult vascular leaf (PO:0006340).
This terms is used only for seed plants, although non-seed plants may have a comparable phase during which they produce juvenile or transition leaves.

tissue.label: seedling development stage
description: A sporophyte vegetative stage (PO:0007134) that succeeds the seed germination stage (PO:0007057) and terminates with the development of the first adult vascular leaf (PO:0006340).

treatment.label: plant experimental condition
description: A plant exposure (PECO:0001001) and/or study type (PECO:0007231) applied to a whole plant (PO:0000003), a plant structure (PO:00090119), and/or a plant population as part of an experiment to evaluate the plant response.

The Plant Experimental Condition Ontology describes the treatments, growing conditions, and/or study types used in various types of plant biology experiments. The subjects of the studies may also include in vitro plant structures (PO:0000004). The broadest classes are the plant study types (PECO:0007231), where the terms describe the type of growth facility used in an experiment.  Each study type such as field study (PECO:0007256), growth chamber study (PECO:0007269), greenhouse study (PECO:0007248), or laboratory study (PECO:0007255) will also involve different growing conditions, and may also include specific biotic (PECO:0007357) and/or abiotic (PECO:0007191) plant treatments.  A plant treatment (PECO:0001001) may be a component of a plant experimental condition (PECO:0007359), and the plant study type (PECO:0007231).

tissue.label: LP.02 two leaves visible stage
description: The stage at which leaves at two nodes, other than the cotyledonary node, are visible above ground.
In grasses, the plant has one leaf plus the coleoptile. The leaves can be a single leaf, two, or whorls of leaves at each node.
synonyms: 1.02 First trifoliolate leaf unfolded in soybean (related)
LP.02 two leaves visible in Solanaceae (related)

treatment.label: salt treatment
description: A chemical treatment (EO:0007189) involving use of salts as supplement to liquid and soil growth media to study various types of responses on their application.
This treatment may be used to simulate the growth conditions of sea coast regions and saline/sodic soils.

treatment.label: experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis
description: An autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system that is produced experimentally in animals by the injection of homogenized brain or spinal cord in Freund's adjuvant. Myelin basic protein appears to be the antigen that elicits the hypersensitivity immune response which is characterized by focal areas of lymphocyte and macrophage infiltration into the brain, associated with demyelination and destruction of the blood-brain barrier. Experimental allergic encephalomyelitis (EAE) is used as an animal model for demyelinating diseases of the human central nervous system such as multiple sclerosis.

An experimental animal model for central nervous system demyelinating disease. Inoculation with a white matter emulsion combined with FREUND'S ADJUVANT, myelin basic protein, or purified central myelin triggers a T cell-mediated immune response directed towards central myelin. The pathologic features are similar to MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS, including perivascular and periventricular foci of inflammation and demyelination. Subpial demyelination underlying meningeal infiltrations also occurs, which is also a feature of ENCEPHALOMYELITIS, ACUTE DISSEMINATED. Passive immunization with T-cells from an afflicted animal to a normal animal also induces this condition. (From Immunol Res 1998;17(1-2):217-27; Raine CS, Textbook of Neuropathology, 2nd ed, p604-5)

tissue.label: rosette leaf
description: A vascular leaf (PO:0009025) born in a circular pattern around a stem (PO:0009047) with compressed stem internodes (PO:0020142).
Arabidopsis, vegetative development is characterized by the production of the rosette leaves.

treatment.label: age-related macular degeneration
description: Age-related loss of vision in the central portion of the retina (macula), secondary to retinal degeneration.

Degenerative changes in the RETINA usually of older adults which results in a loss of vision in the center of the visual field (the MACULA LUTEA) because of damage to the retina. It occurs in dry and wet forms.
Degenerative changes in the macula lutea of the retina.

Degenerative changes in the RETINA usually of older adults which results in a loss of vision in the center of the visual field (the MACULA LUTEA) because of damage to the retina. It occurs in dry and wet forms.
Degenerative changes in the macula lutea of the retina.

description: A vascular leaf (PO:0009025) born in a circular pattern around a stem (PO:0009047) with compressed stem internodes (PO:0020142).
Arabidopsis, vegetative development is characterized by the production of the rosette leaves.

tissue.label: root structure
description: The usually underground part of a seed plant body that originates usually from the hypocotyl, functions as an organ of absorption, aeration, and food storage or as a means of anchorage and support, and differs from a stem especially in lacking nodes, buds, and leaves.

tissue.label: root structure
description: The usually underground part of a seed plant body that originates usually from the hypocotyl, functions as an organ of absorption, aeration, and food storage or as a means of anchorage and support, and differs from a stem especially in lacking nodes, buds, and leaves.

tissue.label: shoot system
description: A collective plant organ structure (PO:0025007) that produces shoot-borne portions of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) and the plant structures (PO:0009011) that arise from them.

The shoot system is generally used to refer to the above-ground plant parts, although some plants have parts of their shoot system underground. For example, a rhizome (PO:0004542), bulb (PO:0025356), a corm (PO:0025355) or a subterranean tuber (PO:0004547), as in Solanum tuberosum (potato) or yam, are all part of the shoot system.
synonyms: シュート系、苗条系 (Japanese, exact)

treatment.label: warm/hot temperature regimen
description: The treatment involving an exposure to above optimal temperature, which may depend on the study type or the regional environment.

treatment.label: experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis
description: An autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system that is produced experimentally in animals by the injection of homogenized brain or spinal cord in Freund's adjuvant. Myelin basic protein appears to be the antigen that elicits the hypersensitivity immune response which is characterized by focal areas of lymphocyte and macrophage infiltration into the brain, associated with demyelination and destruction of the blood-brain barrier. Experimental allergic encephalomyelitis (EAE) is used as an animal model for demyelinating diseases of the human central nervous system such as multiple sclerosis.

An experimental animal model for central nervous system demyelinating disease. Inoculation with a white matter emulsion combined with FREUND'S ADJUVANT, myelin basic protein, or purified central myelin triggers a T cell-mediated immune response directed towards central myelin. The pathologic features are similar to MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS, including perivascular and periventricular foci of inflammation and demyelination. Subpial demyelination underlying meningeal infiltrations also occurs, which is also a feature of ENCEPHALOMYELITIS, ACUTE DISSEMINATED. Passive immunization with T-cells from an afflicted animal to a normal animal also induces this condition. (From Immunol Res 1998;17(1-2):217-27; Raine CS, Textbook of Neuropathology, 2nd ed, p604-5)

description: The treatment involving an exposure to above optimal temperature, which may depend on the study type or the regional environment.

treatment.label: experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis
description: An autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system that is produced experimentally in animals by the injection of homogenized brain or spinal cord in Freund's adjuvant. Myelin basic protein appears to be the antigen that elicits the hypersensitivity immune response which is characterized by focal areas of lymphocyte and macrophage infiltration into the brain, associated with demyelination and destruction of the blood-brain barrier. Experimental allergic encephalomyelitis (EAE) is used as an animal model for demyelinating diseases of the human central nervous system such as multiple sclerosis.

An experimental animal model for central nervous system demyelinating disease. Inoculation with a white matter emulsion combined with FREUND'S ADJUVANT, myelin basic protein, or purified central myelin triggers a T cell-mediated immune response directed towards central myelin. The pathologic features are similar to MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS, including perivascular and periventricular foci of inflammation and demyelination. Subpial demyelination underlying meningeal infiltrations also occurs, which is also a feature of ENCEPHALOMYELITIS, ACUTE DISSEMINATED. Passive immunization with T-cells from an afflicted animal to a normal animal also induces this condition. (From Immunol Res 1998;17(1-2):217-27; Raine CS, Textbook of Neuropathology, 2nd ed, p604-5)

The shoot system is generally used to refer to the above-ground plant parts, although some plants have parts of their shoot system underground. For example, a rhizome (PO:0004542), bulb (PO:0025356), a corm (PO:0025355) or a subterranean tuber (PO:0004547), as in Solanum tuberosum (potato) or yam, are all part of the shoot system.
synonyms: シュート系、苗条系 (Japanese, exact)

treatment.label: warm/hot temperature regimen
description: The treatment involving an exposure to above optimal temperature, which may depend on the study type or the regional environment.

tissue.label: root structure
description: The usually underground part of a seed plant body that originates usually from the hypocotyl, functions as an organ of absorption, aeration, and food storage or as a means of anchorage and support, and differs from a stem especially in lacking nodes, buds, and leaves.

treatment.label: warm/hot temperature regimen
description: The treatment involving an exposure to above optimal temperature, which may depend on the study type or the regional environment.

treatment.label: experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis
description: An autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system that is produced experimentally in animals by the injection of homogenized brain or spinal cord in Freund's adjuvant. Myelin basic protein appears to be the antigen that elicits the hypersensitivity immune response which is characterized by focal areas of lymphocyte and macrophage infiltration into the brain, associated with demyelination and destruction of the blood-brain barrier. Experimental allergic encephalomyelitis (EAE) is used as an animal model for demyelinating diseases of the human central nervous system such as multiple sclerosis.

An experimental animal model for central nervous system demyelinating disease. Inoculation with a white matter emulsion combined with FREUND'S ADJUVANT, myelin basic protein, or purified central myelin triggers a T cell-mediated immune response directed towards central myelin. The pathologic features are similar to MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS, including perivascular and periventricular foci of inflammation and demyelination. Subpial demyelination underlying meningeal infiltrations also occurs, which is also a feature of ENCEPHALOMYELITIS, ACUTE DISSEMINATED. Passive immunization with T-cells from an afflicted animal to a normal animal also induces this condition. (From Immunol Res 1998;17(1-2):217-27; Raine CS, Textbook of Neuropathology, 2nd ed, p604-5)

tissue.label: rosette leaf
description: A vascular leaf (PO:0009025) born in a circular pattern around a stem (PO:0009047) with compressed stem internodes (PO:0020142).
Arabidopsis, vegetative development is characterized by the production of the rosette leaves.

treatment.label: plant experimental condition
description: A plant exposure (PECO:0001001) and/or study type (PECO:0007231) applied to a whole plant (PO:0000003), a plant structure (PO:00090119), and/or a plant population as part of an experiment to evaluate the plant response.

The Plant Experimental Condition Ontology describes the treatments, growing conditions, and/or study types used in various types of plant biology experiments. The subjects of the studies may also include in vitro plant structures (PO:0000004). The broadest classes are the plant study types (PECO:0007231), where the terms describe the type of growth facility used in an experiment.  Each study type such as field study (PECO:0007256), growth chamber study (PECO:0007269), greenhouse study (PECO:0007248), or laboratory study (PECO:0007255) will also involve different growing conditions, and may also include specific biotic (PECO:0007357) and/or abiotic (PECO:0007191) plant treatments.  A plant treatment (PECO:0001001) may be a component of a plant experimental condition (PECO:0007359), and the plant study type (PECO:0007231).

tissue.label: multicellular organism
description: Anatomical structure that is an individual member of a species and consists of more than one cell.

treatment.label: naive thymus-derived CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cell
description: An antigen inexperienced CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cell with the phenotype CCR7-positive, CD127-positive and CD62L-positive. This cell type develops in the thymus. This cell type is also described as being CD25-negative, CD62L-high, and CD44-low.

These cells have not been exposed to antigen following thymic T-cell selection; found in blood and secondary lymphoid organs. This cell type is compatible with the HIPC Lyoplate markers for 'naive CD4+ T cell', but includes additional markers known to be expressed on naive CD4+ T cells.
synonyms: naive thymus-derived CD4-positive, alpha-beta T lymphocyte

description: Anatomical structure that is an individual member of a species and consists of more than one cell.

treatment.label: stenosing tenosynovitis
description: A disorder characterised by catching or locking of the involved finger.

treatment.label: 10x 3' v2
description: 10X 3' v2 is the second version of the 10x sequencing technology that sequences from the 3' end of nucleic acid molecules. In the 3' assay, the polyd(T) sequence is part of the gel bead oligo (which also contains the 10x Barcode, UMI, and partial Illumina Read 1 sequence), with the template switch oligo (TSO) supplied in the RT Primer.

treatment.label: naive thymus-derived CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cell
description: An antigen inexperienced CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cell with the phenotype CCR7-positive, CD127-positive and CD62L-positive. This cell type develops in the thymus. This cell type is also described as being CD25-negative, CD62L-high, and CD44-low.

These cells have not been exposed to antigen following thymic T-cell selection; found in blood and secondary lymphoid organs. This cell type is compatible with the HIPC Lyoplate markers for 'naive CD4+ T cell', but includes additional markers known to be expressed on naive CD4+ T cells.
synonyms: naive thymus-derived CD4-positive, alpha-beta T lymphocyte

treatment.label: 10x 3' v2
description: 10X 3' v2 is the second version of the 10x sequencing technology that sequences from the 3' end of nucleic acid molecules. In the 3' assay, the polyd(T) sequence is part of the gel bead oligo (which also contains the 10x Barcode, UMI, and partial Illumina Read 1 sequence), with the template switch oligo (TSO) supplied in the RT Primer.

tissue.label: seedling development stage
description: A sporophyte vegetative stage (PO:0007134) that succeeds the seed germination stage (PO:0007057) and terminates with the development of the first adult vascular leaf (PO:0006340).
This terms is used only for seed plants, although non-seed plants may have a comparable phase during which they produce juvenile or transition leaves.

tissue.label: rosette
description: A collective leaf structure (PO:0025022) consisting of a group of rosette leaves (PO:0000014), generally borne at the base of the plant, that are separated by very short stem internodes (PO:0020142).

treatment.label: salt treatment
description: A chemical treatment (EO:0007189) involving use of salts as supplement to liquid and soil growth media to study various types of responses on their application.
This treatment may be used to simulate the growth conditions of sea coast regions and saline/sodic soils.

tissue.label: shoot system
description: A collective plant organ structure (PO:0025007) that produces shoot-borne portions of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) and the plant structures (PO:0009011) that arise from them.

The shoot system is generally used to refer to the above-ground plant parts, although some plants have parts of their shoot system underground. For example, a rhizome (PO:0004542), bulb (PO:0025356), a corm (PO:0025355) or a subterranean tuber (PO:0004547), as in Solanum tuberosum (potato) or yam, are all part of the shoot system.
synonyms: シュート系、苗条系 (Japanese, exact)

treatment.label: plant experimental condition
description: A plant exposure (PECO:0001001) and/or study type (PECO:0007231) applied to a whole plant (PO:0000003), a plant structure (PO:00090119), and/or a plant population as part of an experiment to evaluate the plant response.

The Plant Experimental Condition Ontology describes the treatments, growing conditions, and/or study types used in various types of plant biology experiments. The subjects of the studies may also include in vitro plant structures (PO:0000004). The broadest classes are the plant study types (PECO:0007231), where the terms describe the type of growth facility used in an experiment.  Each study type such as field study (PECO:0007256), growth chamber study (PECO:0007269), greenhouse study (PECO:0007248), or laboratory study (PECO:0007255) will also involve different growing conditions, and may also include specific biotic (PECO:0007357) and/or abiotic (PECO:0007191) plant treatments.  A plant treatment (PECO:0001001) may be a component of a plant experimental condition (PECO:0007359), and the plant study type (PECO:0007231).

tissue.label: root
description: A plant axis (PO:0025004) that lacks shoot axis nodes (PO:0005004) and usually grows indeterminately.

Roots function in the absorption of water and inorganic nutrients, anchoring the plant body to the substrate and supporting it, storage of food and nutrients, and vegetative reproduction. The roots of most vascular plant species enter into symbiosis with soil-borne microorganisms. Roots are usually positively geotropic and found underground, although there are many exceptions such as the aerial roots of orchids. Roots often form secondary thickening from the root lateral meristem (PO:0006308). Commonly thought of as one of the three basic parts of the plant body, along with the shoot axis (PO:0025029) and leaves (PO:0025034).

treatment.label: plant stress

description: A plant axis (PO:0025004) that lacks shoot axis nodes (PO:0005004) and usually grows indeterminately.

Roots function in the absorption of water and inorganic nutrients, anchoring the plant body to the substrate and supporting it, storage of food and nutrients, and vegetative reproduction. The roots of most vascular plant species enter into symbiosis with soil-borne microorganisms. Roots are usually positively geotropic and found underground, although there are many exceptions such as the aerial roots of orchids. Roots often form secondary thickening from the root lateral meristem (PO:0006308). Commonly thought of as one of the three basic parts of the plant body, along with the shoot axis (PO:0025029) and leaves (PO:0025034).

treatment.label: plant stress
description: A biological process of some plant (PO whole plant, or NCBI viridiplantae) caused by exposure to an environment containing some stressor agent.

tissue.label: shoot system
description: A collective plant organ structure (PO:0025007) that produces shoot-borne portions of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) and the plant structures (PO:0009011) that arise from them.

The shoot system is generally used to refer to the above-ground plant parts, although some plants have parts of their shoot system underground. For example, a rhizome (PO:0004542), bulb (PO:0025356), a corm (PO:0025355) or a subterranean tuber (PO:0004547), as in Solanum tuberosum (potato) or yam, are all part of the shoot system.
synonyms: シュート系、苗条系 (Japanese, exact)

treatment.label: plant experimental condition
description: A plant exposure (PECO:0001001) and/or study type (PECO:0007231) applied to a whole plant (PO:0000003), a plant structure (PO:00090119), and/or a plant population as part of an experiment to evaluate the plant response.

The Plant Experimental Condition Ontology describes the treatments, growing conditions, and/or study types used in various types of plant biology experiments. The subjects of the studies may also include in vitro plant structures (PO:0000004). The broadest classes are the plant study types (PECO:0007231), where the terms describe the type of growth facility used in an experiment.  Each study type such as field study (PECO:0007256), growth chamber study (PECO:0007269), greenhouse study (PECO:0007248), or laboratory study (PECO:0007255) will also involve different growing conditions, and may also include specific biotic (PECO:0007357) and/or abiotic (PECO:0007191) plant treatments.  A plant treatment (PECO:0001001) may be a component of a plant experimental condition (PECO:0007359), and the plant study type (PECO:0007231).

tissue.label: shoot system
description: A collective plant organ structure (PO:0025007) that produces shoot-borne portions of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) and the plant structures (PO:0009011) that arise from them.

The shoot system is generally used to refer to the above-ground plant parts, although some plants have parts of their shoot system underground. For example, a rhizome (PO:0004542), bulb (PO:0025356), a corm (PO:0025355) or a subterranean tuber (PO:0004547), as in Solanum tuberosum (potato) or yam, are all part of the shoot system.

description: A biological process of some plant (PO whole plant, or NCBI viridiplantae) caused by exposure to an environment containing some stressor agent.

tissue.label: cultured plant cell
description: A plant cell (PO:0009002) that is grown or maintained in vitro.
Includes isolated plant cells and small plant cell aggregates that proliferate while suspended in sterile liquid medium or spread on a solid agar medium.

treatment.label: androecium
description: A collective phyllome structure (PO:0025023) composed all of the stamens (PO:0009029) in a flower (PO:0009046).

The androecium also has as parts any staminodes (PO:0009077) that may be present in a flower. If annotating gene expression to an androecium with a single stamen (PO:0009029), the annotation should go on stamen. If you are annotating to this structure for Zea mays, please also add an annotation to the corresponding floret type. Choose the most specific term possible from: spikelet floret (PO:0009082), ear floret (PO:0006354), lower floret of pedicellate spikelet of ear (PO:0006353), lower floret of sessile spikelet of ear (PO:0006351), upper floret of pedicellate spikelet of ear (PO:0006350), upper floret of sessile spikelet of ear (PO:0006352), tassel floret (PO:0006310), lower floret of pedicellate spikelet of tassel (PO:0006313), lower floret of sessile spikelet of tassel (PO:0006315), upper floret of pedicellate spikelet of tassel (PO:0006314), upper floret of sessile spikelet of tassel (PO:0006316). The development of an androecium in an ear floret of a normal maize plant is aborted and is present in a rudimentary state, while the development of an androecium in a tassel floret leads to a functional androecium.
synonyms: androecium of upper floret of pedicellate spikelet of tassel (exact)

treatment.label: root
description: A plant axis (PO:0025004) that lacks shoot axis nodes (PO:0005004) and usually grows indeterminately.

Roots function in the absorption of water and inorganic nutrients, anchoring the plant body to the substrate and supporting it, storage of food and nutrients, and vegetative reproduction. The roots of most vascular plant species enter into symbiosis with soil-borne microorganisms. Roots are usually positively geotropic and found underground, although there are many exceptions such as the aerial roots of orchids. Commonly thought of as one of the three basic parts of the plant body, along with the shoot axis (PO:0025029) and leaves (PO:0025034).

tissue.label: shoot system
description: A collective plant organ structure (PO:0025007) that produces shoot-borne portions of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) and the plant structures (PO:0009011) that arise from them.

The shoot system is generally used to refer to the above-ground plant parts, although some plants have parts of their shoot system underground. For example, a rhizome (PO:0004542), bulb (PO:0025356), a corm (PO:0025355) or a subterranean tuber (PO:0004547), as in Solanum tuberosum (potato) or yam, are all part of the shoot system.
synonyms: シュート系、苗条系 (Japanese, exact)

treatment.label: control
description: A control role is borne by a material in a process in which results obtained from an experimental sample and a control sample are compared.

treatment.label: plant experimental condition
description: A plant exposure (PECO:0001001) and/or study type (PECO:0007231) applied to a whole plant (PO:0000003), a plant structure (PO:00090119), and/or a plant population as part of an experiment to evaluate the plant response.

The Plant Experimental Condition Ontology describes the treatments, growing conditions, and/or study types used in various types of plant biology experiments. The subjects of the studies may also include in vitro plant structures (PO:0000004). The broadest classes are the plant study types (PECO:0007231), where the terms describe the type of growth facility used in an experiment.  Each study type such as field study (PECO:0007256), growth chamber study (PECO:0007269), greenhouse study (PECO:0007248), or laboratory study (PECO:0007255) will also involve different growing conditions, and may also include specific biotic (PECO:0007357) and/or abiotic (PECO:0007191) plant treatments.  A plant treatment (PECO:0001001) may be a component of a plant experimental condition (PECO:0007359), and the plant study type (PECO:0007231).

description: A plant exposure (PECO:0001001) and/or study type (PECO:0007231) applied to a whole plant (PO:0000003), a plant structure (PO:00090119), and/or a plant population as part of an experiment to evaluate the plant response.

The Plant Experimental Condition Ontology describes the treatments, growing conditions, and/or study types used in various types of plant biology experiments. The subjects of the studies may also include in vitro plant structures (PO:0000004). The broadest classes are the plant study types (PECO:0007231), where the terms describe the type of growth facility used in an experiment.  Each study type such as field study (PECO:0007256), growth chamber study (PECO:0007269), greenhouse study (PECO:0007248), or laboratory study (PECO:0007255) will also involve different growing conditions, and may also include specific biotic (PECO:0007357) and/or abiotic (PECO:0007191) plant treatments.  A plant treatment (PECO:0001001) may be a component of a plant experimental condition (PECO:0007359), and the plant study type (PECO:0007231).

tissue.label: flower
description: A determinate reproductive shoot system (PO:0025082) that has as part at least one carpel (PO:0009030) or at least one stamen (PO:0009029) and does not contain any other determinate shoot system (PO:0009006) as a part.

The characteristic reproductive structure of angiosperms. May have as part one or more petals, sepals or tepals. May contain one or more pistillode (PO:0009078), staminode (PO:0009077) or other aborted organs that don't show up in mature form.

tissue.label: seedling development stage
description: A sporophyte vegetative stage (PO:0007134) that succeeds the seed germination stage (PO:0007057) and terminates with the development of the first adult vascular leaf (PO:0006340).
This terms is used only for seed plants, although non-seed plants may have a comparable phase during which they produce juvenile or transition leaves.

tissue.label: rosette leaf
description: A vascular leaf (PO:0009025) born in a circular pattern around a stem (PO:0009047) with compressed stem internodes (PO:0020142).
Arabidopsis, vegetative development is characterized by the production of the rosette leaves.

tissue.label: root
description: A plant axis (PO:0025004) that lacks shoot axis nodes (PO:0005004) and usually grows indeterminately.

Roots function in the absorption of water and inorganic nutrients, anchoring the plant body to the substrate and supporting it, storage of food and nutrients, and vegetative reproduction. The roots of most vascular plant species enter into symbiosis with soil-borne microorganisms. Roots are usually positively geotropic and found underground, although there are many exceptions such as the aerial roots of orchids. Roots often form secondary thickening from the root lateral meristem (PO:0006308). Commonly thought of as one of the three basic parts of the plant body, along with the shoot axis (PO:0025029) and leaves (PO:0025034).

tissue.label: IL.00 inflorescence just visible stage
description: An inflorescence detectable phase during which an inflorescence is just visible, but has not yet reach one quarter of its full length.

Includes the time when the inflorescence can be seen by removing outer leaves or bracts, or when the inflorescence is visible as a swelling of the outer leaves or bracts, such as booting in Zea. This phase can only be used if the final length of the inflorescence is known.

description: Stage of microgametophyte development during which the pollen reaches mature stage and desiccates.
Mature pollen stages is reached at three-celled pollen in some angiosperms (maize, rice and Arabidopsis), while in others, the maturepollen has two haploid cells (tobacco, snapdragon).

description: A sporophyte vegetative stage (PO:0007134) that succeeds the seed germination stage (PO:0007057) and terminates with the development of the first adult vascular leaf (PO:0006340).
This terms is used only for seed plants, although non-seed plants may have a comparable phase during which they produce juvenile or transition leaves.

tissue.label: IL.00 inflorescence just visible stage
description: An inflorescence detectable phase during which an inflorescence is just visible, but has not yet reach one quarter of its full length.

Includes the time when the inflorescence can be seen by removing outer leaves or bracts, or when the inflorescence is visible as a swelling of the outer leaves or bracts, such as booting in Zea. This phase can only be used if the final length of the inflorescence is known.

tissue.label: subterranean tuber epidermis
description: A shoot axis tuber epidermis (PO:0025046) that is part of a subterranean shoot axis tuber (PO:0004547).
The skin of young potatoes is epidermis while the skin of mature potatoes is periderm.
synonyms: 地下塊茎 表皮 (Japanese, exact)

tissue.label: rosette leaf
description: A vascular leaf (PO:0009025) born in a circular pattern around a stem (PO:0009047) with compressed stem internodes (PO:0020142).
Arabidopsis, vegetative development is characterized by the production of the rosette leaves.

tissue.label: flower
description: A determinate reproductive shoot system (PO:0025082) that has as part at least one carpel (PO:0009030) or at least one stamen (PO:0009029) and does not contain any other determinate shoot system (PO:0009006) as a part.

The characteristic reproductive structure of angiosperms. May have as part one or more petals, sepals or tepals. May contain one or more pistillode (PO:0009078), staminode (PO:0009077) or other aborted organs that don't show up in mature form.

description: The stage at which leaves at ten nodes, other than the cotyledonary node, are visible above ground.
The leaves can be a single leaf, two, or whorls of leaves at each node.

tissue.label: L mature pollen stage
description: Stage of microgametophyte development during which the pollen reaches mature stage and desiccates.
Mature pollen stages is reached at three-celled pollen in some angiosperms (maize, rice and Arabidopsis), while in others, the maturepollen has two haploid cells (tobacco, snapdragon).

tissue.label: cotyledon
description: A vascular leaf (PO:0009025) formed at the first shoot node (PO:0005004) of a plant embryo (PO:0009009) or a seedling (PO:0000003).

tissue.label: root
description: A plant axis (PO:0025004) that lacks shoot axis nodes (PO:0005004) and usually grows indeterminately.

Roots function in the absorption of water and inorganic nutrients, anchoring the plant body to the substrate and supporting it, storage of food and nutrients, and vegetative reproduction. The roots of most vascular plant species enter into symbiosis with soil-borne microorganisms. Roots are usually positively geotropic and found underground, although there are many exceptions such as the aerial roots of orchids. Roots often form secondary thickening from the root lateral meristem (PO:0006308). Commonly thought of as one of the three basic parts of the plant body, along with the shoot axis (PO:0025029) and leaves (PO:0025034).

The roots of most vascular plant species enter into symbiosis with soil-borne microorganisms. Roots are usually positively geotropic and found underground, although there are many exceptions such as the aerial roots of orchids. Roots often form secondary thickening from the root lateral meristem (PO:0006308). Commonly thought of as one of the three basic parts of the plant body, along with the shoot axis (PO:0025029) and leaves (PO:0025034).

tissue.label: cotyledon
description: A vascular leaf (PO:0009025) formed at the first shoot node (PO:0005004) of a plant embryo (PO:0009009) or a seedling (PO:0000003).

tissue.label: hypocotyl

tissue.label: shoot system
description: A collective plant organ structure (PO:0025007) that produces shoot-borne portions of meristem tissue (PO:0009013) and the plant structures (PO:0009011) that arise from them.

The shoot system is generally used to refer to the above-ground plant parts, although some plants have parts of their shoot system underground. For example, a rhizome (PO:0004542), bulb (PO:0025356), a corm (PO:0025355) or a subterranean tuber (PO:0004547), as in Solanum tuberosum (potato) or yam, are all part of the shoot system.
synonyms: シュート系、苗条系 (Japanese, exact)

treatment.label: plant experimental condition
description: A plant exposure (PECO:0001001) and/or study type (PECO:0007231) applied to a whole plant (PO:0000003), a plant structure (PO:00090119), and/or a plant population as part of an experiment to evaluate the plant response.

The Plant Experimental Condition Ontology describes the treatments, growing conditions, and/or study types used in various types of plant biology experiments. The subjects of the studies may also include in vitro plant structures (PO:0000004). The broadest classes are the plant study types (PECO:0007231), where the terms describe the type of growth facility used in an experiment.  Each study type such as field study (PECO:0007256), growth chamber study (PECO:0007269), greenhouse study (PECO:0007248), or laboratory study (PECO:0007255) will also involve different growing conditions, and may also include specific biotic (PECO:0007357) and/or abiotic (PECO:0007191) plant treatments.  A plant treatment (PECO:0001001) may be a component of a plant experimental condition (PECO:0007359), and the plant study type (PECO:0007231).

treatment.label: drought environment
description: an environment in plant experiments to understand how plants respond to episodic drought and watering pulse by depriving the plants of water supply

tissue.label: root
description: A plant axis (PO:0025004) that lacks shoot axis nodes (PO:0005004) and usually grows indeterminately.

The shoot system is generally used to refer to the above-ground plant parts, although some plants have parts of their shoot system underground. For example, a rhizome (PO:0004542), bulb (PO:0025356), a corm (PO:0025355) or a subterranean tuber (PO:0004547), as in Solanum tuberosum (potato) or yam, are all part of the shoot system.
synonyms: シュート系、苗条系 (Japanese, exact)

treatment.label: plant experimental condition
description: A plant exposure (PECO:0001001) and/or study type (PECO:0007231) applied to a whole plant (PO:0000003), a plant structure (PO:00090119), and/or a plant population as part of an experiment to evaluate the plant response.

The Plant Experimental Condition Ontology describes the treatments, growing conditions, and/or study types used in various types of plant biology experiments. The subjects of the studies may also include in vitro plant structures (PO:0000004). The broadest classes are the plant study types (PECO:0007231), where the terms describe the type of growth facility used in an experiment.  Each study type such as field study (PECO:0007256), growth chamber study (PECO:0007269), greenhouse study (PECO:0007248), or laboratory study (PECO:0007255) will also involve different growing conditions, and may also include specific biotic (PECO:0007357) and/or abiotic (PECO:0007191) plant treatments.  A plant treatment (PECO:0001001) may be a component of a plant experimental condition (PECO:0007359), and the plant study type (PECO:0007231).

treatment.label: drought environment
description: an environment in plant experiments to understand how plants respond to episodic drought and watering pulse by depriving the plants of water supply

tissue.label: root
description: A plant axis (PO:0025004) that lacks shoot axis nodes (PO:0005004) and usually grows indeterminately.

Roots function in the absorption of water and inorganic nutrients, anchoring the plant body to the substrate and supporting it, storage of food and nutrients, and vegetative reproduction. The roots of most vascular plant species enter into symbiosis with soil-borne microorganisms. Roots are usually positively geotropic and found underground, although there are many exceptions such as the aerial roots of orchids. Roots often form secondary thickening from the root lateral meristem (PO:0006308). Commonly thought of as one of the three basic parts of the plant body, along with the shoot axis (PO:0025029) and leaves (PO:0025034).

tissue.label: multicellular organism
description: Anatomical structure that is an individual member of a species and consists of more than one cell.

treatment.label: warm/hot temperature regimen
description: The treatment involving an exposure to above optimal temperature, which may depend on the study type or the regional environment.

tissue.label: multicellular organism
description: Anatomical structure that is an individual member of a species and consists of more than one cell.

treatment.label: plant stress
description: A biological process of some plant (PO whole plant, or NCBI viridiplantae) caused by exposure to an environment containing some stressor agent.
